text: Kazan Divi is a rich and creamy milk
pudding with a burned bottom it's
basically the Ottoman precursor to creme
brulee you can flavor the milk pudding
with pretty much anything you want you
could use vanilla you could use
rosewater or you could use mastic mastic
is the crystallized SAP of a pine tree
and it's fabulous it's floral it's piney
it's earthy and I'm gonna grind it up
with a little bit of sugar the sugar is
really important because what the sugar
does is it's abrasive and it helps break
down the mastic the best place to buy
mastic is on Chios in Greece where
they're famous for their mastic
production however you can also order it
online from a spice store so what I have
here is I have the basis for this
pudding it's just a simple cornstarch
mixture cornstarch dissolved in milk a
little bit of sugar and then cooked
until it thickens so you take a little
bit of your milk pudding put it in the
bottom of a pan and then you really let
it cook over a flame until it is the
brown side of black and now the fun part
the burning so make sure to use an oven
mitt for this because you're going to be
holding on to it I think the trickiest
part of this recipe for people is to
have the nerve to cook the bottom layer
dark enough think toasted marshmallow
Brown think rich flavor if you take it
off while it's still golden you're not
gonna get that same punch okay you see
over here here that's it that's perfect
see that see how it's like
blackish-brown that's what you want Sam
tell you this takes this takes guts you
gotta stay with it yeah and look that's
all that that not done
you got a peak as you're burning that
bottom layer you need to keep moving the
pan around because they're gonna be hot
spots they're gonna be cooler spots and
you're looking for an even brown color
okay now this is good and when you're
good
act fast now I'm just gonna flavor the
rest of this pudding with the bastok and
touch of vanilla and then the rest of
the custard just goes right on top you
need to make this at least six hours
ahead or even the day before you want to
serve it because it needs to firm up in
the fridge yes this dessert goes
beautifully with Turkish coffee but I
really love it with a cute little glass
of Turkish tea
